text:
I made a couple of slight changes in order to gamma correct the final image so as to smooth out the rays a little.

For anyone interested in experimenting with the effect, you could pretty much drop any scene into the "Buf A" tab, tweak the light offset, etc, in the "Image" tab, and it should work well enough.
yep, now working. niiiice ! (and fast !)
I'm going to take a close look at this code; thank you for the descriptive comments in the code!
thanks for the documentation... will be nice to review slowly ;)
Awesome, and thanks for the shout-out in the comments and description :)
:love:
Nice effect! Looks expensive. :)
It works now. Looks great!
This is awesome. A cool way to use the light (death) rays...

@Duke and Fabrice
I appreciate the help, as I'm sure you each have better things to do. :) I changed the "m" function to "map." I built this up from scratch using an old, small code template with short variable and function names. Perhaps it was a naming conflict thing.
It seems the problem is in "m" function. When I change it to another noise functions it starts to work.
the mix line 242 brings all the bg orange. strangely if I suppress the mix, the scene is quite dark, and if I reset to 64 line 78 it is black.

@Fabrice and Duke
I'd defined "FAR" inside one of the functions, instead of globally. Now, it's global. I'm assuming some systems put it into global space anyway, whereas others don't. Does that change things?
in bufA::78 if I down the 64 to 30 I see a kind of 3D cubic network in a dense semi-transparent pinky-orange haze.  (which probably dominates all at 64).
Fantastic !
if in main() I directly draw the content of bufA I just have a plein pilnky orange
on linux, I just see a huge sun covering most of the screen.

@Duke
Thanks for going through the trouble to post the image. However, it's difficult to fix errors without the ability to replicate them. The idea behind this is to render a basic scene into "Buf A," read it in from the "Image" tab, then radial blur it. Pretty straight forward stuff.

From what I can gather from the image, the lattice structure perhaps isn't showing up, then just the background is being blurred out? Out of curiosity, if you transcribe the scene from "Buf A" into the "Image" tab, then delete "Buf A," does it render as a normal scene? I'm trying to figure out which tab is causing the problems.

On another note, on my older computer, IE refuses to render a lot of the stuff on Shadertoy these days, including this (instruction count, maybe), so I've given up trying to accommodate it.
Cool
OK on Win7 + Chrome here. Great effect, nice work.
Very nice mashup!
wow
I think that it looks wrong on my Chrome and Firefox http://i.imgur.com/131hBg3.jpg
